title: Adjectives — Describing Words in Detail
description: Students explore adjectives as words that describe nouns, learning to identify them in sentences and use Montessori grammar symbols. They build rich descriptions using sensory adjectives for sight, sound, touch, taste, and smell.
instructions:
1. Review nouns and verbs with grammar symbols.
2. Introduce adjectives: words that describe nouns — they tell us what kind, how many, or which one.
3. Present the Montessori grammar symbol for adjectives (dark blue triangle).
4. Read sentences and identify the adjectives.
5. Play the adjective game: describe an object using five senses.
6. The child writes sentences with vivid adjectives.

slides.heading: Adjectives
slides.subheading: Words That Describe and Paint Pictures
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of our adventure today! It tells us we're going to learn all about "Adjectives," which are super fun words that help us paint a clear picture with our words, just like an artist uses colors.

items: Montessori grammar symbol cards (noun, verb, adjective)
Prepared adjective word cards (colors, sizes, textures, temperatures)
Sentence strips with blanks for adjectives
slides.setup_instructions: Lay out grammar symbols. Prepare sentence strips with blanks where adjectives should go. Gather 5 interesting objects with distinct textures, colors, or shapes for the sensory game.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for our adjective adventure! We have special cards with symbols for nouns and verbs that you already know, and a new one for adjectives – that's the dark blue triangle. We also have word cards with describing words, sentence strips with missing words, your journal, a pencil, and five interesting little things to touch, see, and smell. Go grab all these, and then we'll be ready to play!

slides.text: You already know nouns (black triangle) name things and verbs (red circle) show actions. Today we meet the ADJECTIVE — the word that describes a noun. Its symbol is a dark blue triangle, smaller than the noun triangle, because it depends on the noun.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, remember how nouns are like the stars of our sentences, naming people, places, or things, and verbs are the actions they do? Well, today we're meeting the adjective, the word that tells us *more* about the noun! Its symbol is a little dark blue triangle, smaller than the noun's triangle, because adjectives are like helpers that describe the noun.

slides.text: Listen: 'The dog ran.' Now: 'The enormous, shaggy, brown dog ran.' Which sentence paints a better picture? Adjectives tell us WHAT KIND (brown), HOW MANY (three), or WHICH ONE (that). They make our language colorful!
slides.mascot_explanation: Think about the difference between "The dog barked" and "The fluffy, loud, brown dog barked." See how the second sentence gives you so much more information? That's what adjectives do! They tell us *what kind* of noun it is (like brown), *how many* there are, or *which one* we're talking about, making our sentences much more exciting.

slides.text: Let us use our five senses to find adjectives! Pick up this pinecone. Sight: brown, small, oval. Touch: rough, bumpy, prickly. Smell: woodsy, fresh. Each describing word is an adjective. Place the blue triangle symbol above each one.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's try describing something with our senses! Grab that pinecone. We can see it's brown and small, we can feel it's rough and prickly, and we can smell its woodsy scent. Each of those describing words is an adjective, and we'll put the little blue triangle symbol above each one to show it's describing the pinecone.

slides.text: Now fill in the sentence strips. 'The ___ cat sat on the ___ mat.' Choose adjectives that create a clear picture. Try different ones — 'sleepy orange cat' versus 'fierce black cat' — same sentence, completely different picture!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be a sentence artist! Here are some sentence strips with blanks, like "The ___ cat sat on the ___ mat." Your job is to pick some describing words, called adjectives, to fill in those blanks and make the sentence super interesting. You can try "sleepy orange cat" or maybe "fierce black cat" – see how different adjectives change the whole picture?

slides.prompt: Choose 3 objects from the basket. For each object, write 5 adjectives using your senses (one for each sense if possible). Then write 4 complete sentences using at least 2 adjectives each. Place the dark blue triangle symbol above every adjective. Challenge: Can you write a sentence with 4 adjectives before the noun?
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to really explore! Pick three cool objects and use your senses to write down five describing words for each one – try to get one for each sense if you can! Then, write four sentences using at least two adjectives each, and remember to put that little blue triangle symbol above every adjective you use. Wow, you can even try to fit four adjectives before a noun in one sentence – that's a big challenge!

slides.text: Adjectives are the artist's words — they paint pictures in the reader's mind! A good writer chooses adjectives carefully to create exactly the right image. Tomorrow, keep noticing adjectives everywhere you read.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify adjectives in sentences, place the correct grammar symbol, and use sensory adjectives to describe objects?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You learned that adjectives are like magic words that paint pictures in our minds, and you did a fantastic job describing things using your senses and making your sentences come alive. Remember how you made those sentences so interesting with your chosen words? Keep looking for those colorful adjective words everywhere you read!

parent_notes: The Montessori approach to grammar is concrete and visual. The dark blue triangle for adjectives is smaller than the black noun triangle because adjectives depend on and modify nouns. Encourage your child to notice adjectives in everyday reading. Playing 'describe it' games at meals or on walks builds vocabulary naturally. Avoid correcting creative adjective choices — the goal is fluency and confidence.

title: Multi-Digit Subtraction with Borrowing — Golden Beads
description: Students learn multi-digit subtraction with regrouping (borrowing) using golden bead material. They physically exchange a ten-bar for ten units to make subtraction possible when the top digit is smaller than the bottom digit.
instructions:
1. Review subtraction without borrowing as a warm-up.
2. Present a problem requiring borrowing: 43 - 17.
3. Set up 43 with golden beads: 4 ten-bars and 3 unit beads.
4. Try to take away 7 units — not enough! Exchange 1 ten-bar for 10 units.
5. Now we have 3 tens and 13 units. Take away 7 units = 6 units. Take away 1 ten = 2 tens. Answer: 26.
6. Practice with several more problems.
7. Record each step on paper.

slides.heading: Subtraction with Borrowing
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us the title of what we're learning today: Subtraction with Borrowing! It also tells us we'll be using special golden beads to help us understand how to subtract when we don't have enough of a certain number. It's like a fun math adventure!

items: Place value mat with columns for hundreds, tens, units
Prepared problem cards with borrowing required
slides.setup_instructions: Set up the place value mat. Have plenty of golden beads available, especially unit beads for exchanges. Prepare 8-10 subtraction problems that require borrowing in the ones place.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready for our math adventure! We'll need the golden beads – these are like pretend money, with little single beads for ones, long sticks for tens, and flat squares for hundreds. We also need a special mat to put our beads on, and a notebook and pencil to write things down. Make sure you have all these things with you, maybe ask a grown-up to help you find them!

slides.text: Let us subtract 43 - 17. Set up 43 on the mat: 4 ten-bars in the tens column, 3 unit beads in the units column. Now try to take away 7 units. Wait — we only have 3 units! We cannot take 7 from 3!
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's our first math puzzle: 43 minus 17. We've set up the number 43 on our mat with golden beads – four long sticks for the tens and three little beads for the ones. Now, we need to take away 7 ones, but look! We only have 3 ones. We can't take 7 away from 3, can we? This is where the borrowing magic happens!

slides.text: Here is the secret: we EXCHANGE. Take 1 ten-bar back to the bank and trade it for 10 unit beads. Now we have 3 ten-bars and 13 unit beads. The VALUE is still 43 (30 + 13 = 43), but now we CAN subtract!
slides.mascot_explanation: Uh oh, we don't have enough ones! But don't worry, we can "borrow" from the tens! Watch this: we take one of our long ten-sticks and trade it in at the "bank" for ten little unit beads. Now we have one less ten-stick, but we have ten more unit beads, so we have 13 ones! See? The number 43 hasn't changed, we just organized it differently so we can subtract.

slides.text: Take away 7 units from 13 units = 6 units remain. Take away 1 ten from 3 tens = 2 tens remain. Answer: 26! On paper, we show this by crossing out the 4, writing 3 above it, crossing out the 3, and writing 13 above it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now that we have 13 ones, we can totally take away 7! When we do that, we have 6 ones left. We also took away one of our ten-sticks earlier, so we only have 2 ten-sticks left. Put it all together, and our answer is 26! On paper, we show this by changing the 4 to a 3 and the 3 to a 13.

slides.text: Try 52 - 28. Set up 52: 5 tens and 2 units. Can we take 8 from 2? No! Exchange 1 ten for 10 units: now 4 tens and 12 units. 12 - 8 = 4 units. 4 - 2 = 2 tens. Answer: 24.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try another one, 52 minus 28. We set up 52 with 5 ten-sticks and 2 unit beads. Can we take 8 unit beads away from just 2? Nope! So, we do our special borrowing trick again: trade one ten-stick for 10 unit beads. Now we have 4 ten-sticks and 12 unit beads. Now we can subtract: 12 take away 8 leaves 4, and 4 tens take away 2 tens leaves 2 tens. Our answer is 24!

slides.prompt: Solve with golden beads and record each step in your math journal: 1) 61 - 25, 2) 34 - 18, 3) 72 - 37, 4) 85 - 49, 5) 50 - 23. For each one, draw the exchange step showing how many tens and units you have before and after borrowing. Circle problems where you needed to borrow.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the math explorer! You'll solve these problems using your golden beads and draw the steps in your notebook, especially showing when you trade a ten for ten ones. Remember to circle the problems where you had to do that cool borrowing trick! You can do it!

slides.text: Borrowing is really just EXCHANGING — trading 1 ten for 10 units so we have enough to subtract. The total value never changes, just how it is organized. This is the same idea as making change with money!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform multi-digit subtraction with borrowing using golden beads and record the process on paper?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job with subtraction today! You learned how to "borrow" by trading a ten-stick for ten little beads, which is a super smart way to solve tough problems. It's just like when you trade a dollar bill for four quarters – the value stays the same, you just change how you have it! You are a math whiz!

parent_notes: Borrowing (regrouping) is one of the most challenging arithmetic concepts. The golden beads make it tangible — the child physically exchanges a ten-bar for 10 units, which makes the abstract algorithm concrete. Do not rush to paper-only methods. Let your child work with beads for as long as needed. Some children need weeks of concrete practice before the written algorithm makes sense. Patience here prevents years of confusion later.

title: Ancient Greece — The Birthplace of Democracy
description: Students learn about Ancient Greece as the origin of democracy, exploring how Athenian citizens voted on laws, the agora as a meeting place, and comparing Greek democracy to modern government. They consider who was and was not included.
instructions:
1. Locate Greece on the map and timeline.
2. Introduce the concept: before Greece, most places had kings or pharaohs who made all decisions.
3. Explain Athenian democracy: citizens gathered in the agora to vote on laws.
4. Discuss who could vote (free men) and who could not (women, enslaved people, foreigners).
5. Compare to modern democracy: how is it similar and different?
6. Hold a class vote on a topic to experience democracy.
7. Record key facts in history journal.

slides.heading: Ancient Greece
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the cover of a book, telling us what exciting topic we're going to learn about: Ancient Greece, and how it was the very beginning of democracy! That means we'll discover how people in ancient times figured out a way for everyone to have a voice.

items: Map showing Ancient Greece and the Mediterranean
Small stones or buttons for voting tokens
slides.setup_instructions: Display the map and timeline. Place Greece on the timeline after Egypt and Mesopotamia (around 500 BC for democracy). Prepare voting tokens — the Greeks used pottery shards called ostraka.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our explorer tools ready! We'll need that map to find Greece, and the timeline will show us when all this happened. Your history journal is where we'll write down our discoveries, and these little stones are going to be like the voting pieces the ancient Greeks used. We also have pictures of a special meeting place called the agora.

slides.text: Greece is a land of mountains, islands, and sea in southeastern Europe. Around 2,500 years ago, the Greeks invented something that changed the world forever: DEMOCRACY. The word comes from Greek — 'demos' means people and 'kratos' means power. Democracy means 'power of the people.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide tells us where Greece is and introduces a super important idea they invented: democracy! It means that instead of one king making all the rules, the people themselves get to decide. The word comes from Greek words that mean "people power" – how cool is that?

slides.text: In Athens, citizens gathered in the agora (marketplace) to discuss and VOTE on laws. No king decided for them! If they wanted to build a new temple, citizens debated it and voted. If they thought a leader was becoming too powerful, they could vote to send him away for 10 years — this was called ostracism.
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine a busy marketplace where people gather to talk about everything! That's what the agora was for the ancient Athenians. They would all meet there to discuss and vote on important decisions, like building new things or even deciding if a leader was doing a good job. They were in charge of their own rules!

slides.text: But Athenian democracy was not perfect. Only free men born in Athens could vote — that was about 1 in 5 people! Women, enslaved people, and foreigners could NOT vote. Today, in most democracies, ALL adult citizens can vote. We have expanded the Greek idea to be more fair.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide points out that even though the ancient Greeks had democracy, it wasn't perfect for everyone. Only certain people, like free men, could vote, and lots of people like women and those who were enslaved couldn't join in. It shows us that while they started a great idea, we've made it even better by letting more people vote today.

slides.text: Let us try democracy! We will vote on something together. Each person gets one stone (like the Greeks used pottery pieces). I will propose two options. You will place your stone in the cup for your choice. The majority wins — that is democracy!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's our turn to be like the ancient Athenians! We're going to have our own vote right here. I'll tell you two choices, and you'll use your stone to pick the one you like best. The choice that gets the most stones is the winner – that's how democracy works!

slides.prompt: In your history journal, create a two-column comparison: 'Athenian Democracy' on one side and 'Modern Democracy' on the other. List at least 3 similarities and 3 differences. Then write a paragraph answering: Why was democracy such an important invention? Draw the agora with citizens voting.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to get creative in your history journal! You'll make two lists, one for how democracy worked in Athens and one for how it works now, and find at least three ways they are the same and three ways they are different. Then, think really hard about why democracy was such a big deal and draw a picture of that ancient meeting place.

slides.text: The Greeks gave the world one of its greatest ideas: that ordinary people should have a say in how they are governed. Even though their version was not perfect, the IDEA of democracy has spread to countries all over the world. Every time someone votes, they are continuing what the Greeks started!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what democracy means, describe how Athenian democracy worked, and identify at least two differences between ancient and modern democracy?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we learned so much about how the ancient Greeks started democracy! They came up with the amazing idea that people should get to help make decisions. Even though their way was different from ours, the idea of everyone having a voice is still super important all around the world today.

parent_notes: Ancient Greece is rich territory for critical thinking. The concept of democracy is both inspiring (power to the people!) and complicated (but not ALL people). Encourage your child to think about fairness and inclusion. This is a great time to discuss how your own country's democracy works. If your child is interested, explore the story of Pericles, who led Athens during its golden age, or the contrast between democratic Athens and militaristic Sparta.

title: Europe — Countries, Capitals, and Physical Features
description: Students explore the continent of Europe, identifying major countries, capitals, mountain ranges, rivers, and seas. They learn about Europe's diverse geography from Arctic tundra to Mediterranean coasts.
instructions:
1. Display the puzzle map of Europe.
2. Identify the major regions: Northern, Western, Southern, Eastern Europe.
3. Locate key countries and their capitals: France/Paris, Germany/Berlin, Italy/Rome, Spain/Madrid, United Kingdom/London, Greece/Athens.
4. Identify physical features: Alps, Pyrenees, Rhine River, Danube River, Mediterranean Sea, North Sea.
5. Discuss how geography shaped European history.
6. The child labels a map of Europe.

slides.heading: Europe
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our adventure book about Europe! It tells us we're going to learn all about the different countries in Europe, where their main cities, called capitals, are, and some of the amazing natural things like big mountains and long rivers that make Europe special.

slides.setup_instructions: Set out the puzzle map of Europe. Print a blank outline map for labeling. Open the atlas to Europe. Have the geography journal ready for notes and observations.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, time to get our explorer gear ready! We'll need the cool puzzle map of Europe so we can see where all the countries fit together, an atlas or globe to help us find things, a blank map to draw on later, colorful pencils to make our map look awesome, and a special notebook for writing down interesting facts we discover.

slides.text: Europe is the second-smallest continent but has a HUGE influence on world history! It is connected to Asia (together they form Eurasia) and is surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean, Arctic Ocean, Mediterranean Sea, and North Sea. Let us explore its four regions.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step tells us that Europe is a pretty small continent compared to others, but it's super important in the world! It's connected to Asia, and it's surrounded by big oceans and seas, which means it's been a great place for people to travel and explore. We're going to start by looking at its four main parts.

slides.text: Remove the puzzle pieces as we go. Northern Europe: Norway, Sweden, Finland — land of fjords and the midnight sun. Western Europe: France, Germany, United Kingdom — powerful nations with long histories. Southern Europe: Italy, Spain, Greece — warm Mediterranean climates. Eastern Europe: Poland, Russia — vast plains and forests.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to take the puzzle pieces out and learn about different parts of Europe. We'll see the cold Northern part with Norway and Sweden, the busy Western part with France and the United Kingdom, the sunny Southern part with Italy and Greece, and the big Eastern part with Poland and Russia. Each place has its own special weather and landmarks!

slides.text: Europe has dramatic physical features! The Alps stretch across Switzerland, Austria, France, and Italy — the highest peak is Mont Blanc at 15,781 feet. The Rhine and Danube Rivers were ancient trade highways. The Mediterranean Sea connects Europe to Africa and Asia.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, Europe has some really dramatic natural sights! We're going to learn about the huge Alps mountains, which are like a giant wall, and two very important rivers, the Rhine and the Danube, that have been like highways for boats for a long, long time. We'll also see the beautiful Mediterranean Sea that connects Europe to other parts of the world.

slides.text: Geography shaped history: mountains made natural borders between countries, rivers became trade routes, and the Mediterranean Sea connected civilizations. Greece, which we are studying in history, used the sea for trade and colonization because its land was so mountainous!
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is super interesting because it shows how the land itself helped shape how people lived in Europe a long time ago! Mountains could keep countries separate, rivers made it easy to travel and trade, and places like Greece used the sea to explore and share ideas with others. It's like nature helped decide where people built their homes and cities.

slides.prompt: On your blank map of Europe, label and color at least 10 countries. Mark their capitals with a star. Draw and label the Alps, Pyrenees, Rhine River, Danube River, and Mediterranean Sea. In your geography journal, write 3 facts about Europe that surprised you.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to become map masters! You'll get to take your blank map and draw in at least 10 countries, coloring them in and marking their capitals with a star. Then, you'll draw in those big mountains and rivers we just learned about, and in your notebook, write down three things about Europe that really surprised you.

slides.text: Europe may be small, but its geographic diversity — from Arctic Norway to sunny Greece, from the flat Netherlands to the towering Alps — has created an incredible variety of cultures, languages, and histories. Next time, we will zoom in on specific European countries.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate at least 8 European countries on the puzzle map and identify 3 major physical features?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We explored Europe and learned so much about how its different landscapes, from cold snowy places to warm sunny ones, have made it a really diverse and exciting continent with many different cultures and histories. You did a fantastic job learning about Europe's countries and its amazing physical features!

parent_notes: The Montessori puzzle map of Europe is excellent for kinesthetic learning. Each country is a separate piece that the child can remove, trace, and replace. If you do not have the puzzle map, a large wall map works well. Connect geography to the current history study of Ancient Greece by having the child locate Greece and discuss how its islands and mountains influenced Greek culture. European geography is complex — focus on the big picture first, details later.

title: Read Aloud — James and the Giant Peach, Chapters 1-4
description: Begin reading Roald Dahl's 'James and the Giant Peach,' introducing James Henry Trotter and his terrible aunts. Students discuss character traits, setting, and make predictions about the mysterious old man and the magic crystals.
instructions:
1. Introduce the book and author Roald Dahl.
2. Read chapters 1-4 aloud with expression.
3. Pause to discuss: How does James feel living with Aunt Sponge and Aunt Spiker?
4. Identify character traits of each aunt using adjectives.
5. Discuss the mysterious old man and the green crystals — make predictions.
6. The child draws a scene from the reading.
7. Add new vocabulary to the journal.
materials_needed: James and the Giant Peach by Roald Dahl

slides.heading: James and the Giant Peach
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our new book adventure! It tells us the title is "James and the Giant Peach," and we're going to be reading the first few chapters, called "A Terrible Beginning." This means we're about to meet James and find out what kind of tough start he has.

items: James and the Giant Peach by Roald Dahl
slides.setup_instructions: Find a comfortable reading spot. Have the book and journal ready. Preview the chapters to prepare for reading aloud with expression — Dahl's writing begs for dramatic voices, especially for the horrible aunts!
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us everything we need to get ready for our reading time. We'll need the book, "James and the Giant Peach," our special reading journal, and some pencils for drawing and writing. Make sure you have all these things nearby so we can dive right into the story, and find a cozy spot to read!

slides.text: Today we begin a wonderful book by Roald Dahl, one of the world's most beloved children's authors. Dahl loved to write about ordinary children in extraordinary situations. James is an orphan forced to live with two truly terrible aunts. But something magical is about to happen...
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is telling us about the super fun author, Roald Dahl, who wrote our book! He was amazing at writing stories about kids who find themselves in really wild and unexpected adventures. Today, we'll start reading about James, who has to live with two very mean aunts, but get ready, because something magical is about to happen!

slides.text: As I read, listen for ADJECTIVES — describing words! Dahl is a master of using adjectives to paint vivid pictures. How does he describe Aunt Sponge? Aunt Spiker? The hill? The old man? Keep track of your favorite descriptive words.
slides.mascot_explanation: As we read the story, I want you to be a word detective and listen very carefully for describing words, called adjectives! Roald Dahl uses them to make the story so exciting. Pay attention to how he describes James's horrible aunts, Sponge and Spiker, and anything else in the story – maybe you'll find a new favorite word!

slides.text: After chapters 1-4: James has met a mysterious old man who gives him a bag of magical green crystals. What do you PREDICT will happen? Why do you think the old man chose James? What clues does Dahl give us?
slides.mascot_explanation: After we finish reading the first few chapters, we'll talk about a mysterious old man James meets and some magic green crystals he gets. This is where you get to be a super-smart guesser! We'll think about what those crystals might do and why the old man might have given them to James – what clues does the story give us?

slides.prompt: In your reading journal, create a character page for James, Aunt Sponge, and Aunt Spiker. For each character, write 3-4 adjectives that describe them and draw a small portrait. Then write your prediction: What will the green crystals do? Write at least 3 sentences explaining your prediction.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to show off your amazing ideas! In your journal, you'll draw pictures of James, Aunt Sponge, and Aunt Spiker and write down those describing words we talked about. Then, you get to write your best guess about what those magic green crystals will do – remember to write at least three sentences about your prediction!

slides.text: Roald Dahl begins with darkness — James is lonely, mistreated, and trapped. But the green crystals promise something magical. Great stories often start with a problem that seems impossible to solve. We will find out what happens next time!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe the main characters using adjectives and make a prediction based on story clues?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we learned so much today! We met James and his not-so-nice aunts, and even though things start out sad, we heard about some magic that might change everything. It's like how in many amazing stories, something tricky happens first, but then the adventure really begins!

parent_notes: James and the Giant Peach connects perfectly to this week's language lesson on adjectives — Dahl is extraordinarily descriptive. This book also deals with themes of resilience, friendship, and escaping bad situations, which may resonate with children in various ways. Read with dramatic voices for the aunts! If your child is sensitive, preview the early chapters — the aunts are quite cruel, and James's parents' death (by rhinoceros) is mentioned. Dahl uses humor to balance the darkness.

title: Adjective Placement and Ordering
description: Students discover that adjectives follow a natural order in English (opinion, size, age, shape, color, origin, material, purpose) and practice placing multiple adjectives correctly before nouns.
instructions:
1. Review adjectives from yesterday.
2. Present: 'a red big ball' vs. 'a big red ball' — which sounds right?
3. Introduce the natural order of adjectives.
4. Practice with word cards: arrange adjectives in correct order.
5. Read sentences and identify misplaced adjectives.
6. Write descriptions using multiple adjectives in order.

slides.heading: Adjective Order
slides.subheading: Why We Say 'Big Red Ball' Not 'Red Big Ball'
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure today! It's introducing us to a really cool secret about English words called "adjective order." We're going to figure out why some word combinations sound just right, like "a big red ball," while others sound a little funny, like "a red big ball."

items: Adjective order chart (opinion, size, age, shape, color, origin, material, purpose)
Word cards with various adjectives sorted by category
slides.setup_instructions: Create or print an adjective order chart. Prepare word cards color-coded by category (e.g., size adjectives on one color, color adjectives on another). Have noun cards ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll need for our adjective adventure! We have an "adjective order chart" which is like our map, showing us the secret order. We also have "word cards" with different describing words and "noun cards" for the things we're describing, plus your "language journal" and a pencil to write down all your amazing discoveries.

slides.text: Say these aloud: 'a wooden old table' or 'an old wooden table.' Which sounds natural? English has a SECRET RULE that native speakers follow without thinking: adjectives go in a specific order! Opinion first, then size, age, shape, color, origin, material, purpose.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like a detective game for your ears! Listen closely: does "a wooden old table" or "an old wooden table" sound more like something you'd hear someone say? English has a hidden rule about the order of describing words, and we're going to learn it so we always sound super natural when we talk and write.

slides.text: Example: 'a lovely (opinion) small (size) old (age) round (shape) brown (color) French (origin) wooden (material) dining (purpose) table.' We rarely use that many adjectives at once, but when we use 2 or 3, we follow this order instinctively.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this super long sentence! It's showing us how many different kinds of describing words, or adjectives, can go before a word like "table." Even though we usually only use a couple at a time, they still follow that secret order we're learning, almost like they're lining up for a parade!

slides.text: Practice: arrange these for 'ball' — bouncy, small, red. Answer: 'a small red bouncy ball' — wait, 'bouncy' is purpose! So: 'a small (size) red (color) bouncy (purpose) ball.' Try: beautiful, Italian, leather, old — 'a beautiful old Italian leather [bag].'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the adjective expert! We have some describing words for a "ball," and we need to put them in the right order. Remember that secret rule? We'll figure out if "bouncy" comes before or after "red" and "small" to make it sound just right.

slides.prompt: Using the word cards, build 5 noun phrases with 2-3 adjectives each in the correct order. Write them in your journal. Then write 4 sentences using your phrases. Challenge: Find a sentence in a book that uses multiple adjectives. Copy it and label each adjective's category (size, color, etc.).
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be super creative! You'll use those word cards to build your own describing phrases, like "a fluffy white cloud," and write them down in your journal. Then, you'll write whole sentences using those phrases, and if you're feeling extra adventurous, you can even find a book and see how many describing words you can find!

slides.text: The adjective order rule is one of those magical things about language — you already KNEW the right order, you just did not know you knew it! Now you can explain WHY 'big red ball' sounds right and 'red big ball' sounds wrong.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child arrange 2-3 adjectives in the correct order before a noun and explain the general ordering rule?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! You've unlocked the secret code of adjective order. You already knew in your head what sounded right, and now you can explain *why*! Isn't it neat that you can now tell someone exactly why "a big red ball" is the way to say it and not the other way around? You’re a language wizard!

parent_notes: The adjective order rule is a fascinating linguistic discovery for children — they already follow it intuitively! This lesson makes implicit knowledge explicit. Do not worry about memorizing the full eight-category order; the goal is awareness that order matters. Try this fun test at dinner: say adjective combinations in wrong order and see if the family can fix them. This builds metalinguistic awareness, a key skill for strong readers and writers.

title: Subtraction with Borrowing — Three-Digit Numbers
description: Students extend borrowing to three-digit subtraction problems using golden bead material, learning to borrow from the hundreds place when the tens column also needs regrouping.
instructions:
1. Review two-digit subtraction with borrowing.
2. Present a three-digit problem: 342 - 175.
3. Set up with golden beads: 3 hundreds, 4 tens, 2 units.
4. Work right to left: units first (need to borrow), then tens (may need to borrow again), then hundreds.
5. Show the possibility of double borrowing.
6. Record each step on paper.
7. Practice with more problems.

slides.heading: Three-Digit Subtraction
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us our new math adventure: subtracting bigger numbers, called three-digit numbers! We're going to learn a special trick called "borrowing" to help us solve these tricky problems, just like we did with smaller numbers before.

items: Place value mat (hundreds, tens, units columns)
slides.setup_instructions: Set up the place value mat with three columns clearly labeled. Have ample golden beads ready. Prepare 6-8 problems, some requiring single borrowing and some requiring double borrowing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our math tools ready! We have our golden beads – these little ones are units, these long sticks are tens, and these flat squares are hundreds, helping us see the numbers. We also have a special mat with columns for hundreds, tens, and units to keep us organized, and your math journal and pencil to write down our work. Make sure you have all of these handy so we can start building our numbers!

slides.text: Yesterday we borrowed with two-digit numbers. Today we go bigger! Let us solve 342 - 175. Set up 342: 3 hundred-squares, 4 ten-bars, 2 unit beads. Start with units: take 5 from 2. We cannot! Borrow 1 ten-bar, exchange for 10 units. Now 12 units - 5 = 7 units.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our first big subtraction problem: 342 take away 175. We're going to use our golden beads to show 342. Now, look at the units – we need to take 5 away from 2, but we don't have enough! So, we'll borrow a ten-stick and turn it into 10 little units, then we can take away 5. This is just like when you need one more crayon and borrow it from a friend!

slides.text: Move to tens: we now have 3 ten-bars (after lending 1). Take 7 tens from 3 tens — we cannot! Borrow 1 hundred-square, exchange for 10 ten-bars. Now we have 13 tens - 7 tens = 6 tens. Finally, hundreds: 2 hundreds - 1 hundred = 1 hundred. Answer: 167!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we look at the tens. We started with 4 tens, but we borrowed one, so we only have 3 tens left. We need to take away 7 tens, but we can't! So, we'll borrow a hundred-square and trade it for 10 ten-sticks. Now we have 13 tens, and we can take away 7, leaving us with 6 tens. Then, we take away the hundreds, and we have our answer!

slides.text: That was a DOUBLE borrow — we had to borrow in units AND tens! Let us try one with single borrowing: 458 - 293. Units: 8 - 3 = 5 (no borrow needed). Tens: 5 - 9, need to borrow! Exchange 1 hundred for 10 tens: 15 - 9 = 6. Hundreds: 3 - 2 = 1. Answer: 165.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we just did a *double borrow*! That means we had to borrow in two different places to solve the problem. Now, let's try a problem that might only need one borrow. We’ll set up 458 and subtract 293. First, we check the units: 8 minus 3 is easy, no borrowing needed! But then we'll look at the tens and see if we need to borrow there.

slides.prompt: Solve with golden beads and record in your journal: 1) 523 - 248, 2) 631 - 357, 3) 400 - 156 (tricky!), 4) 712 - 385, 5) 845 - 279. Draw the beads for at least 2 problems showing the exchanges. Circle any problem where you had to borrow TWICE.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the super fun part where you get to be the math wizard! You’ll use your golden beads to solve these problems, just like we practiced, and then draw the steps in your journal. Try to show how you borrowed and traded the beads – that’s how scientists show their work! Don't forget to circle the problems where you had to borrow twice, like we did before.

slides.text: Three-digit subtraction follows the same rule as two-digit: when you do not have enough in a column, exchange from the next column over. Always work right to left — units first, then tens, then hundreds. You can handle BIG subtraction now!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform three-digit subtraction with borrowing (including double borrowing) using golden beads?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! We learned that subtracting big numbers works the same way as small ones: when you don't have enough, you borrow from the next bigger place. You are now a subtraction superstar and can handle even the biggest numbers! Isn't it amazing how you can trade and borrow to figure out tricky math problems?

parent_notes: Three-digit subtraction with double borrowing is a significant milestone. Problem 3 (400 - 156) is especially tricky because there are 0 tens — the child must borrow from hundreds to get tens, then borrow from tens to get units. If this is too challenging, skip it and return later. The golden beads make each exchange visible and logical. Some children may be ready to transition to stamp game or paper methods, but there is no rush.

title: Magnets — Discovering Magnetic Force
description: Students explore magnets and magnetic force through hands-on experimentation. They test various materials to discover which are magnetic, learn about magnetic poles, and observe that magnets can attract and repel.
instructions:
1. Present different magnets: bar, horseshoe, disc.
2. Let the child explore freely — what do magnets do?
3. Introduce vocabulary: attract, repel, magnetic force, poles.
4. Test 15-20 objects: which are magnetic? Which are not?
5. Sort objects into magnetic and non-magnetic groups.
6. Discover the pattern: most magnetic objects contain iron, nickel, or cobalt.
7. Observe attraction and repulsion between magnet poles.
8. Record findings in science journal.
materials_needed: Test objects (paper clips, coins, wood, plastic, aluminum foil, nails, rubber band, glass, keys)

slides.heading: Magnets
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our super cool adventure book about magnets! It tells us we're going to learn about a special, invisible power that magnets have called magnetism. Get ready to be amazed by what these things can do!

items: Bar magnet, horseshoe magnet, and disc magnets
Collection of test objects: paper clips, nails, screws, coins (penny, nickel, quarter), wooden block, plastic spoon, aluminum foil, rubber band, glass marble, brass key, steel key, copper wire
Two bar magnets for pole experiments
slides.setup_instructions: Gather a variety of test objects made from different materials. Have at least two bar magnets with poles clearly marked (N and S). Set up a testing station with objects in a basket and a sorting mat with 'Magnetic' and 'Not Magnetic' labels.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, it's time to gather our detective tools for our magnet investigation! We have different kinds of magnets, like the long bar magnet, the U-shaped horseshoe magnet, and little round disc magnets. We also have a basket full of things to test – like paper clips, nails, coins, and even a wooden block. You'll also need your science journal and a pencil to write down what you discover, and two bar magnets for a special experiment later.

slides.text: Magnets have an invisible superpower — they can push and pull certain objects without touching them! This invisible force is called MAGNETISM. Take a bar magnet and hold it near a paper clip. What happens? The clip jumps to the magnet! The magnet ATTRACTS the paper clip.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about seeing the magic happen! Magnets have this invisible force that can pull some things closer without even touching them. This special pull is called magnetism. Try holding one of your magnets near a paper clip – whoosh! See how it jumps to the magnet? That's called attracting, and it's the first superpower of magnets we're exploring!

slides.text: Now test every object in the basket. Hold the magnet near each one. Does it attract or not? Sort them into two groups: magnetic and not magnetic. Be a scientist — test each object and record your result before moving to the next one.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a super scientist! Take your magnet and carefully hold it near each and every object in your basket, one by one. See if the magnet pulls the object towards it. If it does, that object is magnetic! If it doesn't, it's not magnetic. Make sure to test them all and then sort them into two piles: magnetic and not magnetic.

slides.text: Look at your magnetic group. What do these objects have in common? They all contain IRON, NICKEL, or COBALT — special metals that respond to magnets. Not all metals are magnetic! Aluminum, copper, and gold are metals but NOT magnetic.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look closely at the things you found that *are* magnetic. What do you notice about them? It's like a secret code: most of the magnetic things you found are made of special metals called iron, nickel, or cobalt. Even though things like aluminum foil or copper wire are metal, they don't stick to magnets because they aren't made of these special magnetic metals.

slides.text: Every magnet has two POLES: North (N) and South (S). Take two bar magnets. Bring two N poles together — they REPEL (push away)! Bring N and S together — they ATTRACT (snap together)! Remember: OPPOSITES ATTRACT, LIKES REPEL.
slides.mascot_explanation: Every magnet has two ends, kind of like a superhero with two special powers, called poles! We call them North (N) and South (S). Take two of your bar magnets and try pushing the 'N' end of one towards the 'N' end of the other. Whoa, they push away! That's called repelling. Now try bringing an 'N' and an 'S' together – snap! They pull together, which is attracting. So, remember: opposites attract, and the same poles repel.

slides.prompt: Create a 'Magnet Investigation Report' in your science journal. Make a chart listing every object you tested, what material it is made of, and whether it was magnetic or not. Draw the two rules: 'Opposites attract' and 'Likes repel' with arrows showing the poles. Write 3 sentences explaining what you discovered about which materials are magnetic.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to show off what you've learned in your super science journal! Make a chart to list all the things you tested, what they're made of, and if they were magnetic or not. Then, draw pictures showing how the magnet poles push away (repel) and pull together (attract). Finally, write down three sentences about the coolest things you discovered about which materials magnets like to stick to.

slides.text: Magnets are all around us — in refrigerator doors, speakers, computer hard drives, and even the Earth itself (Earth is a giant magnet!). The invisible force of magnetism follows clear rules: it attracts iron, nickel, and cobalt, and magnets have two poles that attract or repel. Tomorrow we will explore MORE about how magnets work!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify which materials are magnetic, explain what poles are, and demonstrate attraction and repulsion?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did an amazing job investigating magnets! You discovered their invisible force and learned that they can attract some things and repel others, especially when you play with their poles. Magnets are super important and are used in so many things we use every day, from our refrigerators to big machines! Tomorrow, we'll discover even more amazing magnet secrets.

parent_notes: Magnets are endlessly fascinating for children this age. Let your child explore freely before introducing vocabulary — discovery before terminology is the Montessori way. The key concept is that magnetism is selective: not all metals are magnetic, which surprises many children. If you have a compass, show how it responds to magnets — this connects to Earth as a magnet. Avoid letting children put magnets near electronics, credit cards, or pacemakers.

title: Greek Pottery Art — Black and Red Figure Painting
description: Students learn about ancient Greek pottery art, studying the two main styles (black-figure and red-figure) and their depictions of myths, daily life, and athletic events. They create their own Greek-style pottery design.
instructions:
1. Show images of ancient Greek pottery.
2. Explain the two styles: black-figure (black figures on red clay) and red-figure (red clay figures on black background).
3. Discuss common scenes: myths, Olympics, daily life.
4. Note the geometric patterns and borders.
5. The child designs their own Greek vase shape.
6. Create a scene in either black-figure or red-figure style.
7. Add geometric border patterns.

slides.heading: Greek Pottery Art
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the title page of our art adventure! It tells us we're going to be learning all about super old pottery made by the ancient Greeks, and how they painted cool pictures on it using two special styles called black-figure and red-figure. It’s like a sneak peek at the awesome art we’ll be discovering!

items: Printed images of Greek black-figure and red-figure pottery
Black paint, black markers, or black paper
slides.setup_instructions: Print or display several examples of Greek pottery. Cut terracotta paper into vase shapes (amphora, krater, kylix). Have black paint or markers ready. Prepare geometric border pattern examples.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's gather our art supplies! We've got printed pictures of the Greek pottery so we can see what they look like, special rust-colored paper that looks like clay, black paint or markers to do our painting, a pencil for drawing, thin markers for adding small details, and scissors and glue to put everything together. You'll need a grown-up's help to grab all these things!

slides.text: The ancient Greeks were master potters! They made beautiful vases, bowls, and cups decorated with scenes from myths, athletics, and daily life. Greek pottery tells us stories from 2,500 years ago because the pictures are so detailed and expressive.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like our history lesson! It tells us that the ancient Greeks were amazing at making pots, and they decorated them with pictures of exciting things like heroes from myths, people playing sports, and what their lives were like way, way back then. These pictures are so cool because they help us understand stories from thousands of years ago!

slides.text: There were two main styles. BLACK-FIGURE: The artist painted figures in black on the natural red-orange clay. This was the older style. RED-FIGURE: The artist painted the background black and LEFT the figures in the red clay color. This newer style allowed more detail.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're learning about the two painting styles! In the black-figure style, imagine drawing with a black marker on your orange paper, making all the shapes of people and things black. For the red-figure style, it's the opposite: you color the whole background black, and then the people and things you drew stay the color of your orange paper. It's like magic where the color can be inside or outside the shapes!

slides.text: Common scenes include: Hercules fighting the lion, athletes at the Olympics, soldiers in battle, women weaving, and the gods of Mount Olympus. Notice the geometric patterns — meanders (Greek key), waves, and palmettes — used as borders around the scenes.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we get to see what the Greeks painted! They loved drawing heroes like Hercules, athletes running in the Olympics, and even their gods. See those cool zigzag and wavy lines around the pictures? Those are called geometric patterns, and they used them like fancy borders to make their pottery look even more special.

slides.prompt: Choose a vase shape (amphora with two handles, krater with wide mouth, or kylix flat cup). On terracotta paper, draw your vase shape and cut it out. Choose black-figure or red-figure style. Create a scene showing a Greek myth, an athletic event, or daily life. Add geometric border patterns at the top and bottom. Use fine details to make your figures expressive.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's your turn to be a Greek artist! First, pick out a vase shape you like from the examples, like a tall one with handles or a wide bowl. Then, draw it on your rust-colored paper and carefully cut it out. Now, decide if you want to do the black-figure or red-figure style and draw a scene from a myth or the Olympics, adding those neat geometric borders at the top and bottom.

slides.text: Greek pottery is one of our best windows into ancient life because the images tell stories that words sometimes do not. Your pottery design is part of a tradition that is 2,500 years old! Museums around the world treasure these ancient works of art.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the difference between black-figure and red-figure pottery and create a design in one of the two styles?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what you've created! Your amazing artwork is like a story from ancient Greece, just like the pottery they made thousands of years ago. You learned how to tell the difference between black-figure and red-figure painting and even made your own design, which is exactly what those ancient artists did!

parent_notes: This art lesson connects directly to the history study of Ancient Greece. Greek pottery is accessible and engaging — children love the symmetry and storytelling. If you have air-dry clay, the child could shape an actual small pot and paint it. The geometric borders (especially the Greek key/meander pattern) are excellent for developing fine motor control and pattern recognition. Display the finished work as a gallery piece to honor the child's effort.

title: Cooking — Greek-Inspired Soup (Avgolemono)
description: Students learn to prepare a simple Greek egg-lemon soup (avgolemono), connecting cooking to the Ancient Greece history study. They practice measuring, stirring, and following a recipe while learning about Greek cuisine.
instructions:
1. Discuss Greek food culture: Mediterranean diet, olive oil, lemons, yogurt.
2. Read the recipe together.
3. Gather and measure all ingredients.
4. Cook the broth and rice together.
5. Prepare the egg-lemon mixture (temper carefully).
6. Combine and stir.
7. Taste and adjust seasoning.
8. Clean up the cooking area.

slides.heading: Greek Cooking
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is the title of our fun cooking adventure! We're going to learn how to make a special soup from Greece called Avgolemono, which means 'egg-lemon' soup. Isn't it neat that we can make food that people in other countries enjoy?

items: Medium pot, whisk, measuring cups, ladle, bowls
slides.setup_instructions: Gather all ingredients and tools before starting. This recipe requires adult supervision for stove work. The child handles measuring, whisking, and squeezing lemons. Pre-juice the lemons if the child finds squeezing difficult.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is our ingredient and tool gathering mission! We need chicken broth to make our soup base, rice to make it filling, eggs and lemons for that special avgolemono flavor, and salt and pepper to make it taste just right. We also need a pot to cook in, a whisk to mix things up, measuring cups to get the amounts perfect, a ladle to scoop, and bowls to eat from. Go find all these things with a grown-up's help so we can get started!

slides.text: The Greeks eat a Mediterranean diet — lots of olive oil, lemons, fresh vegetables, fish, and yogurt. Today we make AVGOLEMONO (ahv-go-LEH-mo-no), a classic Greek soup. The name means 'egg-lemon' because those are the star ingredients! This soup has been made in Greece for hundreds of years.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like a little peek into Greek eating habits! People in Greece love healthy foods like olive oil, fresh vegetables, and yummy lemons, which are in our soup today. Avgolemono is a super old and famous Greek soup, and making it connects us to that history – how cool is that?

slides.text: Step 1: Bring 4 cups of chicken broth to a boil in the pot. Add 1/3 cup rice. Reduce heat and simmer for 15-20 minutes until rice is tender. While we wait, let us prepare the egg-lemon mixture.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to start cooking! First, we need to carefully pour the chicken broth into the pot and let it get hot and bubbly, like a volcano. Then, we'll add the rice and let it cook until it's soft and yummy. While that's happening, we'll get started on the magical egg-lemon part!

slides.text: Step 2: Whisk 2 eggs in a bowl until smooth. Add the juice of 2 lemons and whisk again. Now the important part — TEMPERING. Slowly add a ladle of hot broth to the egg mixture, whisking constantly. This warms the eggs gently so they do not scramble!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super important egg-lemon part! We're going to gently whisk the eggs and lemon juice together until they're smooth. Then, we'll slowly add a little bit of the hot broth to the eggs while stirring super fast – this is called 'tempering' and it keeps the eggs from turning into scrambled eggs in our soup. You've got this!

slides.text: Step 3: Pour the tempered egg-lemon mixture back into the pot, stirring constantly. The soup will become creamy and slightly thick. Do NOT boil it now or the eggs will curdle. Season with salt and pepper. Taste carefully — it should be tangy and savory!
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's where our soup gets its creamy magic! We'll carefully pour the warm egg-lemon mixture back into the pot, stirring all the time, and watch it get thicker and delicious. Remember, we don't want it to boil now, just get warm. Then we'll add a pinch of salt and pepper, taste it carefully, and see if it needs anything else to be perfect!

slides.prompt: Serve the soup in bowls. As you eat, write the recipe in your own words in a recipe journal or on a card. List the ingredients and steps from memory. Rate the soup on a scale of 1-5 and write what you might change next time. Draw a picture of your bowl of avgolemono.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you made soup! Now it's time to enjoy your delicious Avgolemono. After you taste it, think about what you liked best and write down the recipe in your own words, just like a real chef! You can even draw a picture of your yummy soup and decide if you'd like to add anything different next time.

slides.text: You just made a recipe that Greek families have enjoyed for centuries! Cooking connects us to other cultures and times. The Mediterranean diet is considered one of the healthiest in the world. Next time, we will make bread — another ancient food!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the tempering technique and follow a multi-step recipe with guidance?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You made Avgolemono, a soup that people in Greece have loved for a super long time, and you learned how to temper eggs like a pro! Cooking is a fantastic way to try new foods and learn about different places. Remember how you carefully stirred the soup? That was amazing cooking teamwork!

parent_notes: This cooking lesson connects beautifully to the Ancient Greece history study. Avgolemono is genuinely delicious and simple. The key technique is tempering — slowly warming the eggs with hot broth to prevent scrambling. Let your child do as much as safely possible: measuring, whisking, squeezing lemons. Stove work should be closely supervised. If you have dietary restrictions, substitute vegetable broth and use a different thickener (cornstarch slurry) instead of eggs. The recipe doubles easily for a family meal.

title: Spelling Rules — The Silent E
description: Students discover the magic of silent e: how adding an e to the end of a word changes the vowel sound from short to long. They explore patterns like cap/cape, hop/hope, and kit/kite, building phonemic awareness and spelling confidence.
instructions:
1. Present pairs of words: cap/cape, hop/hope, kit/kite, not/note, tub/tube.
2. Read each pair aloud — notice how the vowel sound changes.
3. Explain the rule: silent e makes the vowel say its name (long vowel sound).
4. The child sorts word cards into short vowel and silent e groups.
5. Build new silent e words from short vowel words.
6. Write sentences using both versions of words.

slides.heading: The Silent E
slides.subheading: The Letter That Changes Everything Without Making a Sound
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the big title for our adventure today! It's telling us we're going to learn about a super special letter, the silent 'e', and how it can change words. It's going to be like a word detective mission!

items: Word pair cards: cap/cape, hop/hope, kit/kite, not/note, tub/tube, pin/pine, mat/mate, bit/bite, rob/robe, cub/cube
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare word pair cards with CVC words on one side and CVCe words on the other. Set up letter tiles so the child can physically add the 'e' to words. Have the spelling journal open to a new page titled 'Silent E Magic.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at all these cool word cards! Each one has two words that look almost the same. We also have these letter tiles, which are like building blocks for words. And see your spelling journal? That's where we'll write down all the amazing words we discover. You'll need a grown-up to help you get these ready.

slides.text: Watch this magic trick! Here is the word 'cap' — c-a-p. Say it. Now I add just ONE letter to the end: e. C-a-p-e. Say it: CAPE. The 'a' changed from a short /a/ sound to a long /ay/ sound! And the 'e'? It is SILENT — it makes no sound at all, but it changed the whole word!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, this is where the magic begins! We're looking at the word 'cap'. Say it out loud. Now, we add a silent 'e' to the end, making it 'cape'. Can you hear how the 'a' sound changed from 'a' like in 'apple' to 'ay' like in 'say'? The 'e' at the end doesn't make a sound, but it totally changed the word for us!

slides.text: The silent e is like a magic wand. It reaches over the consonant and taps the vowel, making it say its own name. Try more: hop (short o) → hope (long o). Kit (short i) → kite (long i). Not (short o) → note (long o). Tub (short u) → tube (long u).
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for more word magic! The silent 'e' is like a little helper that makes the vowel before it say its name, or its long sound. So, 'hop' has a short 'o' sound, but when we add the 'e' to make 'hope', the 'o' says 'oh' instead! We'll do this for 'kit' and 'kite', and 'not' and 'note', and 'tub' and 'tube'.

slides.text: Use your letter tiles. Build 'pin.' Now add an 'e' at the end. P-i-n-e. PINE! The short /i/ becomes long /eye/. Build 'rob.' Add 'e.' ROBE! Build 'mat.' Add 'e.' MATE! The silent e works with ALL five vowels: a, e, i, o, u.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the word builder! Take your letter tiles and make the word 'pin'. Hear that short 'i' sound? Now, add the magic 'e' to the end to make 'pine'. Listen to that 'i' sound now – it's long, like saying its name! Let's do the same for 'rob' to make 'robe', and 'mat' to make 'mate'.

slides.prompt: In your spelling journal, create two columns: 'Short Vowel' and 'Silent E.' Write at least 10 word pairs. Then write 6 sentences, each using BOTH versions of a word pair. Example: 'I wore a cap to Cape Cod.' Challenge: Can you find 3 silent e words that do NOT follow this pattern? (Hint: have, give, come)
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our big activity! We're going to make two lists in your journal: one for short vowel words and one for the silent 'e' words. You'll write down word pairs like 'cap' and 'cape'. Then, you'll write sentences using both words from a pair, like "The cub climbed the tube to the cube." You're going to be a spelling superstar!

slides.text: The silent e is one of the most important spelling rules in English! When you see a word that ends in consonant-e, try the long vowel sound first. And when you are writing and need a long vowel in a one-syllable word, remember — add the magic e!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read CVC and CVCe word pairs correctly, explain the silent e rule, and spell at least 8 silent e words?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! You learned that the silent 'e' is like a secret code that changes vowel sounds in words. Remember, when you see a word ending in 'consonant-e', the vowel probably makes a long sound. You totally rocked learning this new spelling rule!

parent_notes: The silent e rule is one of the most useful spelling patterns in English. It covers hundreds of common words. After this lesson, point out silent e words in everyday reading. Note that some common words break the rule (have, give, come, done, gone) — these are worth mentioning but should not overshadow the pattern. If your child already knows this rule, challenge them with multi-syllable words containing the CVCe pattern: mistake, remote, complete.

title: Multiplication Facts — The 3s Table
description: Students learn multiplication facts for 3 using skip counting, bead chains, and arrays. They discover the pattern that multiplying by 3 means making groups of 3 and connect to repeated addition.
instructions:
1. Review the concept of multiplication as repeated addition.
2. Skip count by 3s together: 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24, 27, 30.
3. Use the short bead chain of 3 to count and mark.
4. Build arrays for 3 x 1 through 3 x 10.
5. Practice facts with flash cards.
6. Discover patterns: all products alternate even/odd; digits sum to 3, 6, or 9.
7. Record facts in math journal.

slides.heading: Multiplication Facts
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our super fun math book! It tells us we're going to learn all about multiplying by 3, and we'll use skip counting and look for cool patterns to help us remember. It's like discovering a secret code for numbers!

items: Montessori short bead chain of 3 (pink beads)
slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the short bead chain of 3. Have individual bead bars ready for building arrays. Prepare grid paper and flash cards. Write '3 x ___' on the board for 1 through 10.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's gather our special math tools for today! See this long string of pink beads? That's our short bead chain, and it helps us count in groups. We also have smaller bead bars, paper with little squares to make pictures called arrays, your math journal and pencil, and some flashcards with multiplication problems. Make sure you have all these ready so we can start our adventure!

slides.text: We know multiplication means equal groups. 3 x 4 means 4 groups of 3 (or 3 groups of 4 — same answer!). Let us master the 3s table today. Start by skip counting: 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24, 27, 30. Say it three times!
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how multiplying is just adding the same number over and over? Like 3 groups of 4 is the same as 4 + 4 + 4. Today, we're going to get super good at multiplying by 3. The first step is to skip count by 3s together, saying the numbers 3, 6, 9, and so on, all the way to 30. Let's say them out loud three times – get that rhythm going!

slides.text: Now use the bead chain. Count every 3 beads and place a ticket: 3 at the first arrow, 6 at the second, 9 at the third. Each ticket shows a multiplication fact! The 4th arrow at 12 means 3 x 4 = 12. Count all the way to 3 x 10 = 30.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's use our special pink bead chain. We're going to count groups of 3 beads and put a little marker, or ticket, on each group. The first ticket will be at the 3rd bead, the second at the 6th bead, and so on. Each ticket shows us a multiplication fact, like the 4th ticket at the 12th bead means 3 times 4 equals 12. We'll do this all the way to the end!

slides.text: Build arrays on grid paper. 3 x 1 = one row of 3 dots. 3 x 2 = two rows of 3 (6 dots). 3 x 5 = five rows of 3 (15 dots). Notice a cool pattern: the products go odd, even, odd, even: 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18... And the digits of each product add up to 3, 6, or 9!
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to make some pictures with dots on our grid paper! We'll build arrays, which are like rows of dots. For 3 x 1, we make one row with 3 dots. For 3 x 2, we make two rows, with 3 dots in each row. Look closely at the numbers of dots we make – notice how they go odd, then even, then odd, then even? That's a super cool pattern!

slides.prompt: Complete the 3s table in your math journal from 3 x 1 to 3 x 12. Draw arrays for 3 x 3, 3 x 5, and 3 x 7. Practice with flash cards until you can answer each 3s fact in under 3 seconds. Write 3 word problems that use multiplication by 3. Example: 'There are 3 shelves with 6 books each. How many books?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to show what you know! In your math journal, write down all the answers for multiplying by 3, from 3 x 1 all the way to 3 x 12. Then, draw those dot arrays for a few problems, and practice with your flashcards until you can answer them super fast! Finally, try making up your own word problems, like "If there are 3 trees and each has 5 birds, how many birds are there?"

slides.text: The 3s have beautiful patterns! Skip counting by 3 is like a rhythm: 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24, 27, 30. And the digit sum trick (adding the digits always gives 3, 6, or 9) helps you check your answers. Practice these facts until they are automatic!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child recite the 3s table to 30, build arrays for 3 x facts, and solve 3s multiplication facts within 5 seconds?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! We learned all about multiplying by 3 today, and you discovered some amazing patterns, like the skip counting rhythm and how the answers always have digits that add up to 3, 6, or 9. Keep practicing those facts, and soon you'll be a multiplication whiz!

parent_notes: The 3s table is often taught after 2s, 5s, and 10s because those have more obvious patterns. The bead chain makes the skip counting concrete and visual. The digit sum pattern is a powerful checking tool: 3 x 7 = 21, and 2 + 1 = 3. If the digits do not sum to 3, 6, or 9, the answer is wrong! Practice 3s facts during car rides, while cooking, or before bed. Fluency with basic facts is essential for later division and fractions.

title: Ancient Greece — The Olympic Games
description: Students learn about the original Olympic Games held in ancient Olympia, comparing them to modern Olympics. They discover which events were included, who could compete, and the significance of the Olympic truce.
instructions:
1. Place the first Olympics (776 BC) on the timeline.
2. Explain: held every 4 years in Olympia to honor Zeus.
3. Describe the events: foot races, wrestling, discus, javelin, chariot racing.
4. Discuss rules: only free Greek men could compete; athletes competed nude.
5. Explain the Olympic truce: all wars stopped during the games.
6. Compare ancient and modern Olympics.
7. Hold a mini-Olympics with simple events.

slides.heading: The Olympic Games
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a really exciting book! It's introducing us to the ancient Olympic Games, which were a super big deal in ancient Greece and are still celebrated today. It's telling us that these games were Greece's greatest festival, which means it was a huge party and competition all rolled into one!

items: Images of ancient Olympic events (vase paintings)
Measuring tape, ball, and open space for mini-Olympics
Olive branch or leaves for winner's wreath
slides.setup_instructions: Mark 776 BC on the timeline. Display images of Greek vases showing Olympic events. Prepare an outdoor or open indoor space for simple athletic events. Make a simple olive wreath from craft supplies or real leaves.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we need for our Olympic adventure! We have a timeline to mark when the games started, pictures of ancient athletes, a journal to write in, and even things for a mini-Olympics like a measuring tape and a ball. We also have some leaves to make a winner's crown, just like they did way back then! Go grab all these things with a grown-up so we can get started!

slides.text: In 776 BC, the Greeks began something that would last for over 1,000 years and inspire our modern world: the OLYMPIC GAMES! Every four years, athletes from all Greek city-states traveled to Olympia to compete. The games honored Zeus, king of the gods.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where our Olympic story really begins! See this date, 776 BC? That's when the very first Olympic Games happened in ancient Greece. They held these games every four years to honor Zeus, who was like the king of all the gods, and guess what? Athletes from all over Greece would come to compete!

slides.text: The events were: the stadion (a 200-meter sprint — our word 'stadium' comes from this!), wrestling, boxing, the pentathlon (5 events: running, jumping, discus, javelin, wrestling), and the thrilling chariot race. Winners received an olive wreath — not gold medals! — and became heroes in their home cities.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for some awesome ancient sports! This slide tells us about the events they had, like a super fast foot race called the 'stadion' – that’s where our word ‘stadium’ comes from! They also had wrestling, boxing, a super tough 5-event challenge called the pentathlon, and even exciting chariot races. Instead of medals, the winners got a simple olive branch crown, but they were still treated like heroes!

slides.text: The most amazing part: the OLYMPIC TRUCE. All wars between Greek cities STOPPED during the games. Armies put down their weapons. Roads became safe for travelers. The Greeks believed athletic competition was more important than fighting. Imagine if the whole world stopped fighting for sports!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is perhaps the most amazing thing about the ancient Olympics: the Olympic Truce! It means that for the time the games were happening, all the fighting and wars between the different Greek cities had to stop completely. Everyone agreed that playing sports together was way more important than fighting each other, which is a really incredible idea!

slides.text: The modern Olympics were revived in 1896 in Athens, Greece. Today, athletes from over 200 countries compete. Women can compete (they could not in ancient times), and there are many more sports. But the spirit is the same: bringing the world together through athletics.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to see how the Olympics have changed! The games we know today started again in 1896, but back then, not everyone could compete, especially girls and women. Now, athletes from all over the world get to join in, and there are tons more sports than there used to be!

slides.prompt: In your history journal, create a comparison chart: Ancient Olympics vs. Modern Olympics. Include: when, where, who competes, events, prizes, and rules. Then hold your own mini-Olympics! Try: a sprint, a standing long jump, and a ball throw (like discus). Measure your distances and record them. Award yourself an olive wreath!
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to be a historian and an athlete! In your journal, you're going to make a chart comparing the old Olympics to the new ones by thinking about who competed, what they did, and what they won. Then, we'll have our own mini-Olympics with a race, a jump, and a ball throw – just like the ancient Greeks! You'll measure how far you went and make yourself a winner's olive wreath!

slides.text: The Olympic Games are one of Ancient Greece's greatest gifts to the world. The idea that nations should put aside their differences and come together in peaceful competition is as powerful today as it was 2,800 years ago. Every modern Olympics opens with a reminder of these Greek origins.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 4 ancient Olympic events, explain the Olympic truce, and compare ancient to modern Olympics?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we've learned so much! The ancient Greeks gave us the amazing idea of the Olympic Games, a time when people can come together peacefully, even if they are usually rivals. It’s like a giant, worldwide sports party that reminds us to be friends, and that’s a pretty cool gift to the world!

parent_notes: The Olympics connect history, geography, culture, and physical education. Children are often surprised that ancient athletes competed nude and that women could not participate. Address these naturally and honestly — they reflect the values of the time. The mini-Olympics is a highlight; measure and record results for an authentic athletic experience. If your child is interested, research which ancient events are still in the modern Olympics (running, wrestling, discus, javelin) and which are new.

title: Europe — The Mediterranean Region
description: Students focus on the Mediterranean region of Europe, exploring Italy, Spain, and Greece. They learn about Mediterranean climate, agriculture (olives, grapes, citrus), and how geography shaped Mediterranean cultures.
instructions:
1. Locate the Mediterranean Sea on the map.
2. Identify countries that border it: Spain, France, Italy, Greece, Turkey, etc.
3. Discuss Mediterranean climate: warm, dry summers; mild, wet winters.
4. Explore agriculture: olives, grapes, citrus, wheat.
5. Connect to Greek cooking lesson: Mediterranean diet.
6. The child creates a product map showing what grows where.
7. Compare Mediterranean climate to the child's home climate.
materials_needed: Images of Mediterranean landscapes and crops

slides.heading: The Mediterranean
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our book about a very special part of Europe called the Mediterranean! It's showing us that the land and water there have helped people create unique ways of living, which is super neat.

items: Images of Mediterranean landscapes, farms, and food
slides.setup_instructions: Display a map centered on the Mediterranean Sea. Gather images showing olive groves, vineyards, citrus orchards, and Mediterranean coastlines. Have drawing materials ready for the product map.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this part, we need to get our explorer tools ready! We'll need a map of the Mediterranean Sea, which is like a big blue puzzle piece in the middle of some countries. An atlas or globe is like a big book of maps to help us find things, and we have some cool pictures of farms and yummy food from there! We'll also need paper and crayons to make our own map, and a special notebook called a geography journal.

slides.text: The Mediterranean Sea is the world's most historically important body of water. Its name means 'middle of the land' — it sits between Europe, Africa, and Asia. Ancient Greeks, Romans, Phoenicians, and Egyptians all sailed these waters for trade, war, and exploration.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is telling us about a super important sea called the Mediterranean Sea. Its name actually means "middle of the land" because it's right between Europe, Africa, and Asia. Long ago, amazing people like the ancient Greeks and Romans sailed all over this sea to explore, trade, and even have battles!

slides.text: Mediterranean climate is special: HOT, DRY summers and MILD, WET winters. This creates perfect conditions for certain crops: olives (which love dry heat), grapes (for wine and raisins), citrus fruits (oranges, lemons), and wheat. Remember our Greek soup with lemon? Lemons thrive in this climate!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to learn about the weather there, which is called the Mediterranean climate! It's really hot and dry in the summer, perfect for things like olives and grapes that love the sunshine. Then, in the winter, it's nice and mild with more rain, which helps other plants grow. Isn't it cool how the weather helps grow specific foods like the lemons we used in our Greek soup?
